articles.headline: Supreme Court Divided on Arbitration for Workplace Cases
articles.snippet: In earlier rulings, the court endorsed arbitration clauses in consumer contracts. A new decision could affect 25 million employment contracts.
articles.abstract: In earlier rulings, the court endorsed arbitration clauses in consumer contracts. A new decision could affect 25 million employment contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its first argument of the new term, the Supreme Court on Monday considered whether to give employers a powerful tool to bar class actions over workplace issues.

articles.headline: Hiking Mountains, Gladly, With a Marine Turned Fund Manager
articles.snippet: Wesley R. Gray, the quantitative investing guru who wants to “get rid of the human,” gets dozens of financial professionals to trek miles for time with him.
articles.abstract: Wesley R. Gray, the quantitative investing guru who wants to “get rid of the human,” gets dozens of financial professionals to trek miles for time with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa. — It was 9 p.m., and about 60 financial executives chattered nervously outside a barrack full of bunk beds at this United States Army training post in central Pennsylvania.

articles.headline: Katzenberg’s Big Ask: $2 Billion for Short-Form Video Project
articles.snippet: After selling DreamWorks Animation last year, Jeffrey Katzenberg is seeking big investors for a new idea. Think “Game of Thrones” in short bites.
articles.abstract: After selling DreamWorks Animation last year, Jeffrey Katzenberg is seeking big investors for a new idea. Think “Game of Thrones” in short bites.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mark Zuckerberg founded Facebook and went looking for investors, his so-called first round of financing was for $1 million. When Travis Kalanick sought financing for Uber, he persuaded investors to ante up $1.25 million. Reed Hastings of Netflix raised $2.2 million.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Chief’s Calendar: A Stream of Industry Meetings and Trips Home
articles.snippet: The calendar of Scott Pruitt, obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, shows fine dining with officials from companies he regulates but few meetings with environmentalists.
articles.abstract: The calendar of Scott Pruitt, obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, shows fine dining with officials from companies he regulates but few meetings with environmentalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For lunch on April 26, Scott Pruitt, the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, dined with top executives from Southern Company, one of the nation’s largest coal-burning electric utilities, at Equinox, a white-tablecloth favorite of Washington power brokers.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Lisa Friedman

articles.headline: Kennedy’s Vote Is in Play on Voting Maps Warped by Politics
articles.snippet: Democratic voters in Wisconsin say gerrymandering the voting districts has given Republicans too much power and violates the Constitution.
articles.abstract: Democratic voters in Wisconsin say gerrymandering the voting districts has given Republicans too much power and violates the Constitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Anthony M. Kennedy has long been troubled by extreme partisan gerrymandering, where the party in power draws voting districts to give itself a lopsided advantage in elections. But he has never found a satisfactory way to determine when voting maps are so warped by politics that they cross a constitutional line.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Equifax Breach Caused by Lone Employee’s Error, Former C.E.O. Says
articles.snippet: Richard F. Smith, the credit bureau’s former top executive, told lawmakers that an “individual” had failed to ensure a problem in Equifax’s software was fixed.
articles.abstract: Richard F. Smith, the credit bureau’s former top executive, told lawmakers that an “individual” had failed to ensure a problem in Equifax’s software was fixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Equifax data breach, which exposed the sensitive personal information of nearly 146 million Americans, happened because of a mistake by a single employee, the credit reporting company’s former chief executive told members of Congress on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Tax Cuts, Sold as Fuel for Growth, Widen Gap Between Rich and Poor
articles.snippet: New research undermines the contention since the 1970s that lower rates stimulate the economy. What they seem to do instead is increase inequality.
articles.abstract: New research undermines the contention since the 1970s that lower rates stimulate the economy. What they seem to do instead is increase inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a little unsettling that the intellectual underpinning of tax policy in the United States today was jotted down on a napkin at the Two Continents Restaurant in Washington in December 1974.

articles.headline: U.S. Expels 15 Cuban Diplomats, in Latest Sign Détente May Be Ending
articles.snippet: The expulsions were intended to force Cuba to place its embassy on the same emergency status that the United States is now operating under in Havana.
articles.abstract: The expulsions were intended to force Cuba to place its embassy on the same emergency status that the United States is now operating under in Havana.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday expelled 15 Cuban diplomats, escalating his response to a mysterious affliction that has stricken American Embassy personnel in Havana in a move that cast a Cold War chill over relations between the two countries.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris, Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Ernesto Londoño
